There are a number of metadata.yaml examples like the following:
stx-platform-helm, stx-rook-ceph, stx-iodc-auth-helm, stx-openstack-helm, etc.
platform_managed_app: yes
or,

There is a difference between yaml boolean and yaml string boolean.
eg, does the resulting value end up a python True, versus the string "yes" or "true".

I hit this inconsistency when handling some existing validation of 'reuse_overrides' flag and 'no_rollback'. Assuming a string boolean will be incorrect if someone specifies reuse_overrides: true vs historically checking for ['true', 'True', 'false', 'False'].

Even though this routine is correct, it now prevents upload of various application tarballs and will display the new error message:
"Application-upload rejected: metadata validation failed. Invalid metadata.yaml: platform_managed_app expected value is a boolean string."

It may be better to use the new routine  _get_metadata_value()  in https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/config/+/778068 , and possibly improve the boolean vs string boolean handling.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I don't think this is a good idea. 

1) The force_down operation is specifically created to ignore safety. The safe way would be to wait until the compute is considered down by the controller and then evacuate. We documented that force_down only applicable if fencing is ensured. If this is ignored then any kind of corruption can happen (ip duplication, volume corruption etc) regardless if the compute service is restarted. So building in safety mechanism to an operation that designed to be unsafe is, I think, going backwards. So I suggest to extend the force_down documentation to state that compute service restart is required before the compute is unforced. 

2) The reported issue is applicable to non forced_down case too. Imagine the following scenario:
* control network fails between a compute host and the controller cluster
* the compute times out and considered down from the controller perspective
* admin issues evacuation of the VMs on this host. The evacuation goes through
* the network failure resolved and the compute service joins back to the cluster without any restart. 

As in this case there is no explicit up action coming from the user, there is no way to reject things. As this can lead to the same corruption than the original bug reported. I think this is a more serious case than the force_down case as here the admin did nothing known to be dangerous. Here I think a mitigation would be to do the evacuation cleanup during a periodic task.

So I think we've come to an agreement in IRC that this is going to be an acceptable thing to do alongside a periodic and other potential changes to ensure things are cleaned up correctly before we force up:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2021-04-01.log.html#t2021-04-01T08:28:24

I'll respin this now to return 400 to avoid a microversion for now so this can be backported before introducing a new microversion in Xena and correctly returning 409.

I'm not sure I agree tbh. Documentation isn't enough to avoid issues like this IMHO and given how trivial the lookup is here it seems like a useful thing to do. What's the downside to codifying this?

This is specifically for the force down, evacuation and force up use case but yeah totally agree that your suggested flow is more likely and it's something I also wanted to look at addressing with a periodic. We actually discussed this at length yesterday during our downstream bug triage call.

Yepp, I'm dropping my -1. I can accept that doing a consistency check at force up could be framed like: Before we take the responsibility back from the admin about this host, we check that what we get is consistent enough. 

I hope this check will not open up a further discussion about making force_down safer. As that is not the goal of that operation.

Unrelated: lol that there's 'done' => 'completed'. The first time I read this, I was thinking, "how is 'done' not an OK state for the cleanup? It's 'done'. Oh, 'completed' is the actual state for all done."
extra thank you for that!

nova/tests/functional/regressions/test_b.message: Is there any easy-to-assert corruption this situation causes? Do we have a resource allocation issue in this case we can assert?
Shouldn't we rather be asserting that we timeout waiting for "completed" status? This feels like a repeat of L60...
I *think* we only cleanup allocations from the source host resource provider once it comes back up so I could assert that here also.

The way the waiter is implemented, it keeps getting the migration status, and exits when it finds the correct one, or timeouts if it never gets it after a certain amount of time. In this case, it will exit on the first attempt, which is why I said that it's repeating L60. The migration could theoretically still move to "completed" after said first attempt. In practice I know it never will, I'm just pointing out that the waiting for "done" doesn't actually add anything. If we want to make the point that the migration never reaches "complete", then we should assert that waiting for "complete" times out.

Anyways, I'm not dying on this hill.
I'm not sure what if any value that would add here. This assertion is quick and confirms that forcing up the original host does nothing to the state of the evacuation migration record.

As the comment says it's asserting that nothing has changed given the compute service being forced up in between, IMHO that's a valid assertion both here when we allow the force up and in the future when we don't.

As you say it can never be `completed` here so a quick assertion using `done` to ensure nothing has changed made sense to me when writing this.

Eh, agree this is weird and seemingly pointless as it will likely always say "yes" it's "done" since it began as "done" even if it were to change like one half second later. I guess really what you'd want to do is pull the migration record again after forcing the compute up and assert it still has status "done". I recognize that this is doing that in one line :) but the "wait for status" words make it a bit odd.

To be clear, I think asserting a status of "done" is valid and I don't think you need to change how you're doing it.

ovsdbapp/event.py.message: Seems like it always returns True :) I understand you want to tell if this is subclassed it can be overridden but if you do "print(event.precheck.__doc__)" then it prints misleading doc for the given object
Would it be possible to add the event only if the precondition is not met in the first place?

Right, (except for the conditional monitoring!) basically some syntactic sugar just to make it easy. The brute force way would just be doing things like:

    event = WaitForSwitch(api, sw, timeout=5)
    api.event_handler.watch_event(event)
    event.wait()
    api.lsp_add(sw, p).execute(check_error=True)

creating the event is cheap, running the event should just be a log n lookup that almost never fail, and if it does then it waits the shortest time possible since we can monitor the event stream.

Transaction objects already have a pre_commit(), but this would essentially be a pre_run() for the Command. It might be good to have the option to disable the checks for things like doing a migration where we know nothing else is writing to the db and we are doing 100s of thousands of operations at once though. There are other optimizations like if you have a transaction that adds multiple ports to a switch, you don't really want to do the same check multiple times either...so we'd probably want to take that into account. But before we start optimizing, I figured I'd just make it possible to do with this patch. :p

That's what this should do. If event.precheck doesn't evaluate to True, then that means the event has overriden precheck, meaning that there are preconditions added and also that they have not been met. Maybe I'm misunderstanding the question though.
You mean have precheck() return false by default? Ideally, the precheck() would be the place for avoiding adding the event (line 140) and hopefully that would be returning false in most cases.

Let me ask if I understand correctly: if we don't have any event, that won't check anything.

Who will add those checks? This is supposed to be requested by the user, not in any command here in the backend, right?

Not sure about the implementation details. Conditional monitoring is known to be expensive so unless I understand wrongly the purpose of Terry's approach, it looks like we'd be setting tons of these events (e.g. adding a NAT rule would make sure that the LSP exist, adding a route would make sure that the LR exist,...) and this could have a big penalty. I might be wrong though...

What I was trying to suggest with my comment is to locally determine whether the onetime event is needed and avoid adding it to the server if not.

Definitely no conditional monitoring. Just listening for the event in our normal event stream.

Essentially, in a multi-server (or even multi-connection) environment, there is absolutely no guarantee that we have received updates that were triggered by other servers. We've just been skating by because generally ovsdb-server responds faster than when someone creates two API requests that happen to hit other servers.

Everything in this patch is entirely local. The only overhead would be doing a lookup (similar to if we passed may_exist=True) and with indexing this should be very cheap.

It is one of those edge cases where you might only hit it very rarely unless a system is really overloaded, but for the code to be correct you really do need to handle the case.

are these files generated when working with upstream intel driver ?

or are these out of tree, vendor specific generated sysfs files ?

to my understanding there is no consensus in kernel about SR-IOV trunk API for SR-IOV legacy (correct me if im wrong)

reason im asking is that im unsure about the community approach towards pushing this in neutron instead of a 3rd party module.

These are *NOT* auto-generated files but written as per the interface exposed by Intel i40e driver. This i40e driver is nothing but SR-IOV legacy driver above a certain version, i.e. anything above 2.7.11 support sysfs:-

https://downloadcenter.intel.com/download/24411/Intel-Network-Adapter-Driver-for-PCIe-40-Gigabit-Ethernet-Network-Connections-Under-Linux-

Its not agreed upon in kernel yet, but that shouldn't stop us from leveraging and integrating what's available at the moment. Other NICs can also add their code to driver.

The interface for TrunkPlumber class is a generic one, I can its implementation a dynamically loadable module via Stevedor. Later on other NIC vendors can either support same sysfs interface of SR-IOV driver and a consensus is made in Kernel about this. Otherwise they can implement this pluggable module and load it via the setup.conf endpoints?

Hi,
Apologies for the delay.
i agree it should not stop integrating whats available. IMO only the API + stevedore module loading should be part of neutron, the vendor specific implementation (i40e related) should be out of tree in a separate python package.

once a consensus is reached in kernel, and there is upstream kernel support, a vendor agnostic implementation can be added to neutron.

Thats only my opinion, i see this feature was open for quite a while and im not sure what was agreed with neutron drivers team about it.

So can this middleware be called remotely? Or how to use such plugin? There will have a new API for this? If there is new API, why not directly user agents APIs.

For the basics of healthcheck plugins:
https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.middleware/latest/reference/healthcheck_plugins.html

I know I'm late to this review, but I mostly agree with Liu here. Why duplicate parts of the agent API? If somebody wants to check agent health we already have everything for it on the API.

To me the parts that makes sense is a low-cost (very fast) check of:

* did auth work?
* is the db connection alive or was a trivial db operation successful?
* is the mq connection alive or was a trivial mq operation successful?

Also how would the current patch work for an agentless plugin?

In addition, the OVN ML2 driver doesn't store agents in the DB. Basically, OVN doesn't use RPC and the agent api looked pretty tied to that, so it overrides the ML2 get_agent() etc. calls and essentially proxies those into lookups in OVSDB, and merges the results with whatever other drivers would return.

It can certainly be argued that this is an unfortunate hack, but regardless, pulling agents directly from the db won't currently get any ovn agents.

This action is time-consuming when there are large sets of ports in ovsdb. Everytime the new device is plug to the bridge, it will scan all records in table Interface. The get_vif_port_by_id's final ovsdbapp call is DbFindCommand which just use idl to get all records and then use the conditions to filter the one you want.

yep. I like it :).  fixed in upcoming patch

I want to also specifically call out - this change will be a breaking change for VM's that are already on a routed network.  As now the bridge that they should be plugged into would be refrenced from the segment uuid and not the network uuid.  Is their a way to migrate these gracefully?  Mainly nova needs to update the vm's domain.xml with the new bridge name.

I don't think that there is any graceful way to do it. Probably user will have to do reboot hard or migration of VMs.
Will existing VMs working fine after upgrade or all will be broken?
Existing VM's will be broken.  As we will move the port that is providing connectivity to the network, to a different bridge.

1) This "network_segment" is a neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.agent._agent_manager_base.NetworkSegment. It has no segment_id because this is not a Neutron network segment, just an agent network segment.

2) Why do you need to create a bridge per segment? For isolation? Two network segments can have the same segmentation ID and the traffic from both segments will be in the same virtual network or tunneled network.

Yes, the bridge names that the VM's attach to do indeed change - they have to.  Since with routed networks the network_id is always the same, but the segments which contain the specific vlan/segment information are those that are unique.  Which will cause issues when you try to bind two segments from the same routed network to the same host.  Everything will get plugged into the same bridge.  All the vm's and vlan specific interfaces.

We are running this code in production and have been since pike. We had a migration script that we ran, when we switched over to this code that allowed us to migrate to the non-conflicting segment based bridges.  With negligible downtime (read < 5 missed pings).  Which basically was: 
Create the new segment based bridge if it didn't exist, create a veth device between the old bridge and the new bridge(keep the traffic flowing when we move vm tap devices).  Move each of the vm taps from the old bridge to the new bridge.  Update the vm's running config and stored xml files to reference the new bridge. Move the vlan device to the new bridge.  Remove the veth, remove the old bridge, restart neutron agent.

My guess this is only required on linux_bridge, because the OVS based code always provides the bridge name to use to neutron.  Rather than the existing code which just provides the network name and nova uses that.  This patch essentially works by causing the port object given to nova to include the bridge_name to use (just like ovs does).  The rest of it is basically making sure that we pass around the segment_id instead of the network_id so things get plugged into the correct places on the neutron side.


Also - this code doesn't do anything with vm ports, if you applied this patch and restarted the neutron agent on a routed network.  what ends up happing is that the vlan port the neutron agent is responsible for managing gets moved to a new segment based bridge id and the existing bridge with the vm's on it loose their networking.  Until they are shutdown/restarted and nova grabs a fresh version of the networkinfo_cache for the vm and rewrites the libvirt xml file with the segment based bridge name.

2.) We create a bridge per segment because in the case where you have two network segments with different vlan_ids (our specific use case we are addressing, (EG having 2 segments with a unique vlan_id, with a /22 per-segment assigned to the same host in a routed network).  Under linux bridge, without this you would create a single bridge, and attach both the vlan interfaces and all the vm's to that bridge.  Then you would be effectively bridging the traffic from vlan say 401 to vlan 402.  This works the same way that creating two separate non-routed networks with different vlanids and mapping those to the same host.

I dont get the use case for creating 2 segments with the same segment_id attached to the same host.  IE two segments on a routed network both with vlan 401 attached to the same host.  As they would both have same vlanID and traffic would mix between those two segments.  But you are specifically trying to say these are and should be separate (by creating a new/different network segment).  If you wanted these to mix, why not just add the additional subnet that is in the other segment to the original segment with the same Id?

I do get the use case of being able to create multiple segments with the same segmentation id and assigning those to different hosts.  IE compute nodes in rack 1 using vlan401 and compute nodes in rack2 using vlan401 as well.  But in this case the vlans, while the ID is the same are totally seperate and are local to each rack.  In this use case you shouldn't (in reality can't, without mixing traffic?) have both segments assigned to the same host.

neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py.message:
The "device_owner" check is done in "_get_security_groups_on_port" with "port" content, not "port_updates".

You should not modify "port_updates".

If I'm not wrong, reading the bug description, the problem you spotted out is that a port belonging to "network:" can have a SG assigned. Did you check if "_get_security_groups_on_port" returned False? If port device_owner is "network:*", then is a trusted port.

But "updated_port" has this change. The device_owner parameter was updated in [1], before calling this method [2]. You already have this information updated without changing port_updates.

Another question is (asked in the bug) if the problem is when you are updating a port, changing at the same time the device_owner (to network:*) and the SG. Is that the problem?


[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py#L1664-L1665
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py#L1687-L1688

The "port" is actually a request body. so if the requst body has  no device_owner specified, but has security_groups attr when update a port belonging to "network:" ,  then "_get_security_groups_on_port" can not get the "device_owner" and return the "port" SG, "network:" port subsequently is added SG.
And, "port_updates" is a dict as the "port" dict value.

We can't pass the original port to the "_get_security_groups_on_port" method, as the original port  has no or different SG and other attrs than the port (request body).So just keep the port "device_owner" attr in consistence with the updated port and keep passing the modified port.
That's just my opinion, may be wrong or there may be a better solution.

Then use the original port info in _get_security_groups_on_port. But why you should modify "port_updates"? The goal of is to check that the port is trusted (as checked in "_get_security_groups_on_port"). You can pass the original port to this method.

there is no gareentee that hosts within an AZ have low latency

the AZ could be split into multiple cells at different edge sights.

conversly there is no guarentee of higher reliablity by selecting different AZ an AZ in openstack is not the equivalent of an AZ in aws meaning it is not a seperate fault domain. its is just a metadta tag on a host aggreate.
it has not high avaiablity implication by defualt.

some deployments use it for that other dont.
you are refering to server groups?

yep but again AZ are not actully fault domains in openstack so it typical for multiple AZ to have shared openstack infrasturture and its rather unusal for them to be deployed as completly independed fault domains. to do that you have to have a 1:1 mapping between AZ and nova cells and even then teh non nova compents like placment cinder and neutron woudl also need to be configured to operate in an multipel AZs

service like keystone,glance,swift and placment also dont have the concept of AZ the same way that nova has so an AZ is quite a leaky abstrtion to use to model fault domains.

even if nova has been configured in such a way as to make each AZ a seperate fault domain ist rather unlikely that all other services have been so you instace will still be imapacted if there is a failure of say the keystone service regardless of which az they are in.

unless you use cells V2 to deploy a seperate database/conductor and have a per cell rabbitmq instance per az all az in nova share the same db/message bus and are handeled by the same conducrtor/api/schulder. as such a failure of the contoler services will affect all az in the same cell equally.


cells are not actully a ha mechanisium either but they have some improved resiliance provided the failure is configed to only one cell

e.g. the failure of a cell conductor or cell db will not affect other cells provided that conductor is not also the super conductor.

As we discussed during the last IRC Nova meeting [1], AZ affinity and anti-affinity is already managed by Nova :
* you can specify N instances to be on the same AZ just by specifying the same --availability_zone at boot time
* you can specify N instances to be on distinct AZs by looking over the os-availability-zones API, pick N distinct AZs, and boot each of the N instances using a different --az value corresponding to the AZ you picked

The only miss I see here in this workflow is with multi-create:
* you can specify N instances to be created on the same AZ by using both --max and --az
* but you can't specify N instances to be on mutually exclusive AZs on one single boot command

I'm all open for discussing about the multi-create gap, but I personnally think adding this possibility would require substantial API change which wouldn't be worth it.
I'd personnally recommend you to pursue your efforts into AZ-exclusive multi-create by writing a 3rd-party tool which would orchestrate the AZ exclusion and trigger concurrent API calls accordingly.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova/2020/nova.2020-10-08-16.00.log.html#l-147

given our reluctance to add new functionality to multi-create and the fact that in general we would prefer to remove that api rather then enhance it i would agree with using external tooling for that usecase.

multi create currently reuses the same request spec for all instnace as a way to carry info related to which host the instance are currently schduled too for normal anti afinity

preserving that behavior and allowing az antiafinity would be invaisve to cahnge. im not saying it cant be done but its more work then this spec currently proposes doing and would be required for this to work for multi create.

so the AZ if not set in the boot request will be populated by the api before we reach teh schduler filter using the defualt az set in its nova.conf or nova if no value is configured.

so by the time the request is recived at teh filter it will already be populated int eh build_request/requst_spec and the filter will not be able to tell if the az was requested by the use or populated by the api.

The idea here was to modify the State machine as little as possible. Grammatical oddity aside, the whole quiescence/unquiescence cycle would be understood as a single operation by openstack under this scheme.

A more comprehensive (and complicated) version of state tracking for quiescence has been outlined in the Alternatives section.

For me the state transitions are not clear based on this description. Could you please specify what task state transition will happen when
a) the new os-server-external-events arrives to freeze the instance
b) when qemu-agent finished freezing the instance
c) when the os-server-external-events arrives to unfreeze the instance (or the periodic tasks hits)
d) when unfreezing is finished

I see. The please change the sentences:

"This state will be set once the instance has been successfully quiesced and cleared on a successful unquiescing" 

to something like

"This state will be set once the quiesce os-server-external-event is received and cleared on a successful or failed handling of unquiesce os-server-external-event."

so it reflects that actual step when the task_state is set and unset

Only two transitions for task_state are proposed in this section:
* None -> Quiescing after the event is received
* Quiescing -> None if the operation fails or if unquiescing finishes.

This is meant as a very minimalist version of quiescence tracking. A more complex version has been described in the alternatives section.

Actually, that's a mistake on my part. A generic failure to process and execute an unquiescing operation can't automatically clear the task state, since it's unclear if the actual state of the VMs FS has changed at that point; the original spec is correct.
not sure we should use this API. Since we add an action instead of an event to this API.

We could add an API endpoint instead as described in the Alternatives section. The os-server-external-events method came out of a discussion I had with mriedem on the topic.

As mentioned above, the operation is treated as a synchronous one, which is why only the Task State is used to track it with the -ing suffix denoting the transitional nature of the quiescing operation/state. Additionally, it preempts any naming conflicts and confusions should the full VM state transitions (as described in the alternatives section) be implemented at a future date.

-1: We either make the `os-server-external-events` synchronous for this specific message so it doesn't return until the quiesque is complete (which probably goes against the basis Nova's async messaging API), or we make this API part of the spec and not an alternative.

Otherwise Cinder won't have any way to use this new functionality in any meaningful way.

Once the call is sync or we have the query state call, Cinder's snapshot will be able to:

- Check if volume is attached
- Call Nova to quiesce
- Wait until it is quiesced
- Make the snapshot
- Unquiesque it

unfortunately this is bad idea, because airshipctl may use this file as source for the kubeconfig in the first place. bash redirect ">" deletes old file immediately, so for example if we use this file as source of kubeconfig, airshipctl will have empty file as source and will fail. So as of now, easiest way is to do 

airshipctl cluster get-kubeconfig target-cluster > ~/.airship/kubeconfig-tmp
mv ~/.airship/kubeconfig-tmp ~/.airship/kubeconfig

I will create an issue to add a flag to `airshipctl cluster get-kubeconfig`  command that would allow write it to file. This way we will be sure that first airshipctl uses information from the file, and then overwrites it.

We need to change all scripts in `tools` directory to use `airshipctl cluster get-kubeconfig <clusterName>` when needed, instead of relying on a single premade kubeconfig.

I think point Matt is asking is to make a check before deleting it, so it doesn't fail if there is no file:
[ -f "~/.airship/kubeconfig" ] && rm ~/.airship/kubeconfig

To answer 2nd question from Matt, if we don't delete that kubeconfig, airshipctl will consider it to be a viable source for kubeconfig, and use it. and in our case, it may have kubeconfig from older runs (when testing), its going to fail, because the certificates in the kubeconfig are not valid for new cluster.

Won't the command / script fail if that file doesn't exist?  Do we need to make this conditional?

or even simpler, if we take the `rm` line out, the lines below will overwrite it if it exists anyway, right?

))) Kostyantyn asked similar questions when reviewed that.. Looks like I made a bad job than didn't answer to that comment.

Just in case: this condition is for whole block: rm, get, mv :)
Here is how `airshipctl cluster get-kubeconfig` works. It goes though the list of endpoints in cluster-map [1].
If you look there, you'll see that `~/.airship/kubeconfig` is the first source.
If we don't delete that file, airshipctl won't regenerate that. And we need regenerated set of kubeconfigs from sops, because we just regenerated secrets, right?
Once we deleted that file, when we execute the command it will go the the kustomization bundle after that and we'll get new set of kubeconfigs.
After that we're putting that set to `~/.airship/kubeconfig`, and for all next commands it works like a cache, so airshipctl works a bit quicker, because it doesn't need to decrypt kubeconfig-related secrets. 

As Kostyantyn mentioned here it's just one of several ways on how to approach with handling kubeconfigs. But this approach works and I think that we may keep it as-as because it makes our pipeline a bit quicker.

yes.. the playbook will stop if zuul.repoclosure is defined.  It's a single purpose job in the integration line..   1. setup repos 2. repoclosure 3. go away.   If zuul.repoclosure is not defined then the playbook would continue.

I don't see why a registered var is required.  The job stops if repoclosure fails, the unusual thing here is to stop the job conditionally if it passes.

ok so i think i get it now - sorry and thanks for trying to explain.

the intention is to pass this job.repoclosure in only 1 job, the special new repoclosure job you will be adding. 

So the first task will run on all jobs, when there is a problem it will fail. But this second task should only trigger for that one special job we will be adding as dependency on the others.

can we switch to dnf repoclosure? https://dnf-plugins-core.readthedocs.io/en/latest/repoclosure.html

What about improving this task, go over per repo if no repo is specified then go with dnf repoclosure?
dnf repoclosure --repo rawhide

been trying to determine if they are actually seperate things

on my box i have /usr/bin/repoclosure but also dnf repoclosure and the output seems exactly the same - perhaps the dnf plugin is actually calling /usr/bin/repoclosure?

In any case it probably makes sense to switch to the 'new' dnf repoclosure if /usr/bin/repoclosure is the old yum way.

ya. I agree w/ both of you.  +1 on dnf repoclosure and +1 on making it more customizable.  We'll need to reduce noise in the output from packages we just don't care about.

I'm thinking a jinja template bash script that calls "dnf repoclosure"
would move this when: to the last line to be consistent - or block these two tasks

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Can mysql and postgre tests use same DB engine at the same time? I thought each worker has it's own one..

Right, each one has its own DB engine. Initially it tested using two "group_regex" inputs but I tested using only one (PS2) and each class has its own separate worker. Please, take a look at.
- TestModelsMigrationsMysql: worker 7
- TestModelsMigrationsPsql: worker 3

With this new input parameter we group each DB engine class tests in one worker.

[1]https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/2af941954ceb491c8ec393080856b6b3/log/job-output.txt

The point is that without the input "--group_regex", any test from "TestModelsMigrationsPsq" or "TestModelsMigrationsMysql" is executed randomly by any worker. This could lead to a situation where two or more tests using the same DB engine (MySQL, Postgree) are being executed at the same time. That overloads the DB engine an slows down the test execution.

With this group we ensure all tests using the same backend are executed by the same worker, that implies none of those tests are going to be executed in parallel. This is the goal of this patch.

Sorry, still can't understand this sentence "To avoid overloading the DB engine" - which DB engine is at the risk of being overloaded given that tests are executed by different workers with different DB engines?
Why?

The nodateext setting was removed so that it may be controlled consistently from the logrotation.conf file. I removed this same setting from all of maintenance and fault.
The dateext setting was commented out in logrotate.conf update in the Depends-On update.

We are just trying to drive some (best effort) consistency into the logrotation stuff.

Note that with this and the depends on update change in config-files the log files continue to be number rather than dated extensions.
Thanks Eric - I just wanted to confirm that this wasn't going to change the behaviour.
